docs.lead_paragraph: Philadelphia MENTION medical innovation, and you might think of the biotech corridor around Boston, or the profusion of companies developing wireless medical technologies in San Diego. But one of the most important hotbeds of new approaches to medicine is ... you didn't guess it: Arkansas.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Prof Ezekiel J Emanuel lauds state-wide medical program in Arkansas that will do away with the fee-for-service model, instead bundling together all of a patient's hospital visits, tests and treatments for a single condition; argues that new method encourages doctors and hospitals to work together to provide patients the highest quality care, while lowering costs. (M)

docs.abstract: An experiment in appointing a doctor or hospital as the "quarterback" to be responsible for an episode of patient care.
docs.snippet: An experiment in appointing a doctor or hospital as the "quarterback" to be responsible for an episode of patient care.

headline.main: Live Updates From the Democratic Convention

docs.abstract: The Times will be providing updates and analysis from Charlotte on our live dashboard. You can also follow along on Twitter @thecaucus, or follow our list of Times journalists covering the convention.

docs.lead_paragraph: Democrats had two simple messages for voters: Mitt Romney does not get it, and President Obama does. The main attraction was Mr. Obama’s lead character witness: his wife, Michelle.

headline.seo: Democratic Convention Opens With Pitch to Middle Class
headline.main: Michelle Obama Tops Opening Night for Democrats
headline.sub: First Lady Leads Push to Paint Rivals as Out of Touch
headline.print_headline: First Lady Tops Opening Night For Democrats

docs.abstract: Democratic National Convention opens with a parade of officials telling voters that Mitt Romney does not understand the problems faced by the middle class and culminates with a rousing speech from Michelle Obama arguing that Pres Obama does; Obama sought to remind voters that her husband is the same person they put into office in 2008, despite four years of partisan sniping, Washington gridlock and the continued economic challenges that may have dulled his appeal.
docs.snippet: Democrats had two simple messages for voters: Mitt Romney does not get it, and President Obama does. The main attraction was Mr. Obama’s lead character witness: his wife, Michelle.

docs.lead_paragraph: A look back at Richard Nixon’s stands on big government programs and new regulations underscores how much the political center has moved.

headline.seo: The G.O.P.’s Journey From the Liberal Days of Nixon
headline.main: G.O.P. Shift Moves Center Far to Right
headline.print_headline: G.O.P. Shift Moves Center Far to Right

docs.abstract: Eduardo Porter Economic Scene column notes that the current Republican Party's stance on big government programs and regulations in comparison with that of Richard Nixon's administration four decades ago underscores how much the political center in the United States has shifted to the right.
docs.snippet: A look back at Richard Nixon’s stands on big government programs and new regulations underscores how much the political center has moved.

docs.lead_paragraph: On a recent trip to Africa, Bill Clinton showed how he is bringing his family deeper into the Clinton Foundation, perhaps confronting a future without him.

headline.seo: In Africa, Bill Clinton Toils for a Charitable Legacy
headline.main: Carving a Legacy of Giving (to His Party, Too)
headline.print_headline: Carving a Legacy of Giving (to His Party, Too)

docs.abstract: Bill Clinton will formally place Pres Obama's name into nomination at the Democratic National Convention, in a departure from his work as a global philanthropist and a return to the muddy terrain of partisan politics; Clinton has worked to create a post-presidential legacy of philanthropic endeavors, and as a six-nation tour in Africa in July has shown, he is attempting to deepen his family's involvement in the work of the Clinton Foundation, in part to ensure that the legacy can continue without him.
docs.snippet: On a recent trip to Africa, Bill Clinton showed how he is bringing his family deeper into the Clinton Foundation, perhaps confronting a future without him.
